message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: UAV swarms: research, challenges, and future directions
Paper Abstract: Abstract Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) swarms represent a transformative advancement in aerial robotics, leveraging collaborative autonomy to enhance operational capabilities. This paper provides a comprehensive exploration of UAV swarm infrastructure, recent research advancements, and diverse applications. Key areas such as coordinated path planning, task assignment, formation control, and security considerations are examined, highlighting how Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are integrated to improve decision-making and adaptability. Applications span civilian sectors, including entertainment, infrastructure inspection, and delivery services, as well as military applications in surveillance, combat support, and logistics. The paper addresses technical challenges, regulatory constraints, and ethical considerations, while outlining future directions focused on scalability, robustness, and societal integration. This review consolidates the evolving landscape of UAV swarms, identifying critical challenges and guiding future research endeavors.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about "Formation control":

The search results show that formation control refers to the control of robotic systems, which is a research area in robotics. It involves work in evolutionary and biomorphic robotics and formation control of robotic systems.

Formation control is particularly relevant in the field of multi-robot systems, where the goal is to coordinate multiple robots to maintain a specific geometric configuration or formation while completing tasks. This has applications in swarm robotics, autonomous vehicles, and other collaborative robotic systems.

The search results also returned information about other meanings of "formation" and "control" in different contexts (such as oil well control, political formation processes, and control theory), but the primary technical meaning refers to the coordination and control algorithms used to manage groups of robots moving in organized formations.

If you're looking for more specific information about formation control—such as algorithms, mathematical frameworks, or particular applications—I'd be happy to search for more detailed information.

## Task Assignment Problem - Search Results

Based on the web search, here's an overview of the task assignment problem:

### Definition

The assignment problem is a fundamental combinatorial optimization problem where the problem instance has a number of agents and a number of tasks.(no content)Any agent can be assigned to perform any task, incurring some cost that may vary depending on the agent-task assignment.

### Objective

The solution is whichever combination of agents and tasks results in the least total cost. In other words, the goal is typically to find an assignment that minimizes total cost while ensuring all tasks are completed.

### Variants

The problem has several important variants:

- **Balanced vs. Unbalanced**: When speaking of the assignment problem without additional qualification, the linear balanced assignment problem is meant. An unbalanced version occurs when there are more agents than tasks (or vice versa).

- **Generalized Assignment Problem**: The maximum generalized assignment problem is a problem in combinatorial optimization that is a generalization of the assignment problem in which both tasks and agents have a size.(no content)Each agent has a budget and the sum of the costs of tasks assigned to it cannot exceed this budget, and it is required to find an assignment in which all agents do not exceed their budget and total profit of the assignment is maximized.

### Solution Algorithms

There are many algorithms for finding the optimal assignment in time polynomial in n. The Hungarian algorithm is one well-known solution method for this problem.

I've performed a web search for "Machine Learning" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## What is Machine Learning?

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms, supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Historical Development

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Neural Networks and Deep Learning

In machine learning, a neural network or neural net (NN), also called artificial neural network (ANN), is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks.(no content)Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

The search results provide foundational information about machine learning, its history, applications, and key technical concepts.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of swarm robotics:

## What is Swarm Robotics?

Swarm robotics applies swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.(no content)The approach takes inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.

## Key Principles

Key principles include autonomous robots that can interact with surroundings, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities like wireless transmission systems, do not exploit centralized control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks.(no content)Miniaturization is also a key factor, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the swarm-intelligent approach through a greater number of individual interactions.

## History

The phrase "swarm robotics" first appeared in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research began to grow in the early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, which demonstrated self-organized teams of robots that cooperate to solve complex tasks.

## Applications

Applications include tasks demanding miniaturization, like distributed sensing tasks in micromachinery or the human body.(no content)Swarm robotics is particularly useful for search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots could be sent to places rescue-workers cannot reach safely.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks demanding cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of swarm robotics:

## What is Swarm Robotics?

Swarm robotics applies swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.(no content)The approach takes inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.

## Key Principles

Key principles include autonomous robots that can interact with surroundings, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities like wireless transmission systems, do not exploit centralized control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks.(no content)Miniaturization is also a key factor, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the swarm-intelligent approach through a greater number of individual interactions.

## History

The phrase "swarm robotics" first appeared in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research began to grow in the early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, which demonstrated self-organized teams of robots that cooperate to solve complex tasks.

## Applications

Applications include tasks demanding miniaturization, like distributed sensing tasks in micromachinery or the human body.(no content)Swarm robotics is particularly useful for search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots could be sent to places rescue-workers cannot reach safely.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks demanding cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about aerial robotics:

## Definition and History

The term "aerial robotics" was coined by competition creator Robert Michelson in 1990 to describe a new class of small highly intelligent flying machines.

## Development and Applications

Successive years of competition saw these aerial robots grow from vehicles that could barely maintain themselves in the air, to automatons which are self-stable, self-navigating, and able to interact with their environment.

## Competitive Programs

The field has been significantly advanced through various competitions:

- **International Aerial Robotics Competition (IARC)**: The International Aerial Robotics Competition is a university-based robotics competition held on the campus of the Georgia Institute of Technology, currently hosted by RoboNation. Since 1991, collegiate teams with the backing of industry and government have fielded autonomous flying robots in attempt to perform missions requiring robotic behaviors not previously exhibited by a flying machine.

- **Student Competitions**: The REC Foundation manages a drone competition for students in grades 5-12 known as the Aerial Drone Competition. The Aerial Drone Competition challenges teams' teamwork, programming skills, drone piloting abilities, and communication.

## Real-World Example

The Freewing Scorpion is a reconnaissance UAV of the United States, developed in the early 21st century by Freewing Aerial Robotics Corporation, associated with the University of Maryland, College Park.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Unmanned Aerial Vehicles:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Capabilities

A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.(no content)Unmanned aerial vehicles include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs).

## Historical Development

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)The Spanish engineer Leonardo Torres Quevedo introduced a radio-based control-system called the Telekino at the Paris Academy of Science in 1903.

## Modern Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications.(no content)Civil uses include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, inspections for home insurance, counting wildlife, delivering medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions, and detection of illegal hunting.

## Commercial Growth

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)By 2017, DJI alone had over 75% of the global consumer drone market share.

Web search results for query: "Autonomous system robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot"},{"title":"Self-reconfiguring modular robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-reconfiguring_modular_robot"},{"title":"Service robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_robot"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"Robot control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_control"},{"title":"Delivery robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delivery_robot"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about autonomous system robotics:

## Definition

An autonomous robot is a robot that can perform desired tasks in unstructured environments without continuous human guidance.(no content)According to ISO 8373, robots require "a degree of autonomy", which is the "ability to perform intended tasks based on current state and sensing, without human intervention".

## Key Technologies

The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation. For example, Boston Dynamics' "Spot" is an autonomous robot that uses four sensors and allows the robot to map where it is relative to its surroundings through a navigational method called simultaneous localization and mapping, or "SLAM".

## Applications

Autonomous systems are being deployed across various sectors:

- **Service and Delivery**: Delivery robots are autonomous robots that provide "last mile" delivery services and can be used in different settings such as food delivery, package delivery, hospital delivery, and room service.

- **Healthcare**: Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

- **Domestic Use**: A new area showing commercial promise is domestic robots, with a flood of small vacuuming robots beginning with iRobot and Electrolux in 2002.

## Challenges

Autonomous robots remain highly vulnerable to unexpected changes in real-world environments, as even minor variations like a sudden beam of sunlight disrupting vision systems or unanticipated terrain irregularities can cause entire systems to fail.

Links: [{"title":"Surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surveillance"},{"title":"Mass surveillance in the United Kingdom - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_surveillance_in_the_United_Kingdom"},{"title":"Global surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_surveillance"},{"title":"Mass surveillance in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_surveillance_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of government mass surveillance projects - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_government_mass_surveillance_projects"},{"title":"Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_Intelligence_Surveillance_Act"},{"title":"Intelligence, surveillance, target acquisition, and reconnaissance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligence,_surveillance,_target_acquisition,_and_reconnaissance"},{"title":"Mass surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_surveillance"},{"title":"Surveillance (2008 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surveillance_(2008_film)"},{"title":"List of films featuring surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_films_featuring_surveillance"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about surveillance:

## Definition and Overview

Surveillance is the systematic observation and monitoring of a person, population, or location, with the purpose of information-gathering, influencing, managing, or directing.(no content)It is widely used by governments for a variety of reasons, such as law enforcement, national security, and information gathering.

## Types of Surveillance

Mass surveillance is the intricate surveillance of an entire or a substantial fraction of a population in order to monitor that group of citizens.(no content)The surveillance is often carried out by local and federal governments or governmental organizations, but it may also be carried out by corporations (either on behalf of governments or at their own initiative).

## Government Surveillance Programs

The vast majority of computer surveillance involves the monitoring of data and traffic on the Internet, with automated Internet surveillance computers sifting through intercepted traffic to identify and report suspicious activity. Notable programs include the NSA's PRISM program, which is a data mining system that gives the United States government direct access to information from technology companies, allowing the government to obtain search history, emails, stored information, live chats, file transfers, and more.

## Privacy Concerns

Surveillance can unjustifiably violate people's privacy and is often criticized by civil liberties activists.(no content)Democracies may have laws that seek to restrict governmental and private use of surveillance, whereas authoritarian governments seldom have any domestic restrictions.

I've completed the web search for "Artificial Intelligence." Here's a summary of the findings:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

## History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Types of AI

Artificial general intelligence (AGI)—sometimes called human‑level intelligence AI—is a type of artificial intelligence that would match or surpass human capabilities across virtually all cognitive tasks. In contrast, weak AI (or narrow AI) can solve one specific problem but lacks general cognitive abilities.

## Current Applications

AI has diverse applications across many fields, including healthcare, architecture, media analysis, video surveillance, music composition, and more. Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

## Emerging Concerns

Prodigious power consumption by AI is responsible for the growth of fossil fuel use, and might delay closings of obsolete, carbon-emitting coal energy facilities. Additionally, ethical topics within AI include algorithmic biases, fairness, accountability, transparency, privacy, and regulation, particularly where systems influence or automate human decision-making.

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Probabilistic roadmap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_roadmap"},{"title":"OMPL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OMPL"},{"title":"Kinodynamic planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinodynamic_planning"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_A*"},{"title":"Visibility graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visibility_graph"},{"title":"Navigation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_function"},{"title":"Theta* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theta*"},{"title":"Pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathfinding"}]

I've completed the web search for "Motion planning path planning." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Motion planning, also path planning (also known as the navigation problem or the piano mover's problem) is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Key Algorithms and Approaches

**Sampling-Based Methods**: Sampling-based algorithms represent the configuration space with a roadmap of sampled configurations. A basic algorithm samples N configurations in C, and retains those in Cfree to use as milestones. A roadmap is then constructed that connects two milestones P and Q if the line segment PQ is completely in Cfree.

**Probabilistic Roadmap**: The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics, which solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration of the robot and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

**Any-Angle Path Planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms are pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle.

**Kinodynamic Planning**: In robotics and motion planning, kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

## Real-Time Path Planning

Real-Time Path Planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment.

## Applications

For example, consider navigating a mobile robot inside a building to a distant waypoint. It should execute this task while avoiding walls and not falling down stairs. A motion planning algorithm would take a description of these tasks as input, and produce the speed and turning commands sent to the robot's wheels.

I've completed the web search for "Motion planning path planning." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Motion planning, also path planning (also known as the navigation problem or the piano mover's problem) is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Key Algorithms and Approaches

**Sampling-Based Methods**: Sampling-based algorithms represent the configuration space with a roadmap of sampled configurations. A basic algorithm samples N configurations in C, and retains those in Cfree to use as milestones. A roadmap is then constructed that connects two milestones P and Q if the line segment PQ is completely in Cfree.

**Probabilistic Roadmap**: The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics, which solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration of the robot and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

**Any-Angle Path Planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms are pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle.

**Kinodynamic Planning**: In robotics and motion planning, kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

## Real-Time Path Planning

Real-Time Path Planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment.

## Applications

For example, consider navigating a mobile robot inside a building to a distant waypoint. It should execute this task while avoiding walls and not falling down stairs. A motion planning algorithm would take a description of these tasks as input, and produce the speed and turning commands sent to the robot's wheels.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
